thread.title: See every pole winner in the history of the Great American Race
thread.title_full: See every pole winner in the history of the Great American Race

author: Brian
title: See every pole winner in the history of the Great American Race
text:
Feb 13, 2017 at 5:05p ET 0Shares Sunday at 3 p.m. ET on FOX, qualifying for the 59 th Daytona 500 takes place. To get ready for the roll for the pole at the Great American Race, here are the top qualifiers for all 58 previous Daytona 500s. NASCAR NASCAR via Getty Images 1959, Bob Welborn The very first Daytona 500 pole-winner was Welborn, who qualified at 140.121 mph in his ’59 Chevy. An engine failure after 75 laps left him 41 st in the 59-car field. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1960, Cotton Owens NASCAR Hall of Fame member Owens made it just 149 laps before a transmission failure knocked him out of the race. After qualifying at 149.892 mph, Owens finished 40 th . RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1961-63, Fireball Roberts 
1961 - For the third year in a row, the pole-winner was a DNQ in the race. Fireball Roberts qualified at 149.601 mph but lost an engine in his Smokey Yunick Pontiac after 187 laps. He finished 20 th . 
1962 - For the first time in history, the Daytona 500 pole-winner finished the race. In fact, after qualifying at 152.529 mph, Roberts won the race. 
1963 - For the third year in a row, Roberts took the Daytona 500 pole, but for the second time in those three years, he had an engine failure, finishing 21 st . His pole speed was 160.943 mph. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1964, Paul Goldsmith Speeds took a huge spike upward, as Goldsmith took the pole at 174.910 mph. Goldsmith finished third behind Richard Petty and Jimmy Pardue as Plymouths swept the top three spots. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1965, Darel Dieringer 
Dieringer became the first Mercury driver to claim the pole, with a lap of 171.151 mph in a Bud Moore entry. Dieringer finished second to Fred Lorenzen. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1966, Richard Petty Petty claimed his first Daytona pole at 175.165 miles per hour and went to win the race for the second time, too. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1967, Curtis Turner In the biggest upset in Daytona 500 pole history, Turner claimed the top spot in a Smokey Yunick-owned Chevelle that was only about 7/8 th s scale size compared to a stock Chevelle body. Turner lost an engine in the race. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1968, Cale Yarborough Top-qualifier Yarborough won from the pole after qualifying the Wood Brothers Mercury at 189.222 mph. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1969, Buddy Baker Baker took the pole in Ray Fox’s Dodge Charger 500 at 188.901 mph. Baker finished the race fifth. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1970, Cale Yarborough Yarborough clocked in at 194.015 mph, the first Daytona 500 pole faster than 190 mph. But an engine failure left him 37 th in the race. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1971, A.J. Foyt After qualifying No. 1 at 182.744 mph, Foyt finished third behind Petty Enterprises teammates Richard Petty and Buddy Baker. The Enthusiast Network The Enthusiast Network 1972, Bobby Isaac A great qualifying effort gave Isaac the pole at 186.632 mph, but an engine failure left him 33 rd in the race. This content is subject to copyright. The Enthusiast Network 1973, Buddy Baker Baker qualified No. 1 at 185.662 mph, but lost an engine with six laps to go after leading 156 laps. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1974, David Pearson It was a tough Daytona 500 for Pearson, who finished 35 th due to mechanical problems. His pole speed was 185.017 mph. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1975, Donnie Allison A fuel-pump failure left Allison 28 th after posting a pole speed of 185.827 mph. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1976, Ramo Stott Definitely a surprise pole-winner at 183.456 mph, Stott’s Chevrolet (83) lost an engine, as he finished 26 th . RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1977, Donnie Allison Allison won his second Daytona 500 pole in three years with a speed of 188.048 mph. But he crashed in the race and finished 30 th . RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1978, Cale Yarborough After qualifying on the pole at 187.536 mph, Yarborough finished second to Bobby Allison in a battle of future NASCAR Hall of Fame drivers. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1979-80, Buddy Baker 1979 - For the third time in his career, Baker won the Daytona 500 pole, this time turning a speed of 196.049 mph. But he lost an engine after 38 laps and finished 40 th . 1980 - No issues this time, as Baker put Harry Ranier’s “Gray Ghost” Oldsmobile on the pole at 194.099 mph and set a race speed record of 177.602 mph that still stands today. 1981, Bobby Allison In a year when Richard Petty won his seventh and final Daytona 500, Allison took the pole at 194.624 mph and finished second in the race. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1982, Benny Parsons Although Parsons won the pole at 196.317 mph, a crash left him 26 th in the race results. ISC Archives via Getty Images RacingOne 1983, Ricky Rudd After winning his first Daytona 500 pole at 198.864 mph, Rudd had engine problems in the race and wound up 24 th . 1984, Cale Yarborough By qualifying at 201.848 mph, Yarborough was the first Daytona 500 pole-winner to qualify at more than 200 mph. And he won the race to boot. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1985-87, Bill Elliott 1985 - Elliott was awesome, qualifying on the pole at 205.114 mph and winning the race, too. 1986 - For the second year in a row, Elliott won the pole, this time at 205.039 mph. But he finished a disappointing 13 th . 1987 - A third consecutive Daytona 500 pole for Elliott, who set the all-time track record at 210.364 mph prior to winning for the second time in three years. 1988-1990, Ken Schrader 1988 - Schrader put Rick Hendrick’s Chevrolet on the pole at 193.823 mph and went on to finish sixth in the race. 1989 - A second consecutive pole for Schrader, this time at 196.996 mph. He finished second in the race to Hendrick Motorsports teammate Darrell Waltrip. 1990 - For the third straight year, Schrader sat on pole, this time at 196.515 mph. But an engine failure relegated him to a 40 th -place finish. 1991, Davey Allison Allison took the Daytona 500 pole at 195.955 mph, but finished the race in 15 th . ISC Archives via Getty Images RacingOne 1992, Sterling Marlin The good news: Marlin won the Daytona 500 pole at 192.213 mph. The bad news: Marlin crashed in the race and finished 35 th . 1993, Kyle Petty After winning the pole at 189.426 mph, Petty crashed in the race and finished 31 st . 1994, Loy Allen Jr. One of the most unlikely pole-winners ever, Allen was also the first rookie to win a Daytona 500 pole, clocking in at 191.58 mph. He finished 22 nd in the race. ISC Archives via Getty Images RacingOne 1995, Dale Jarrett A solid fifth-place finish for Jarrett, who qualified on the pole at 196.498 mph. This content is subject to copyright. Getty Images 1996, Dale Earnhardt It was Earnhardt on the pole at 189.510 mph in a Richard Childress Racing Chevrolet, but it was Dale Jarrett’s Ford that beat him to the checkered flag. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1997, Mike Skinner Skinner was the surprise pole-winner at 189.813 mph, finishing a respectable 12 th in his Richard Childress Racing Chevrolet. This content is subject to copyright. Getty Images 1998, Bobby Labonte After qualifying his Joe Gibbs Racing entry on the pole at 192.415 mph, Labonte finished second to Dale Earnhardt. It was the last time a Pontiac sat on the 500 pole. This content is subject to copyright. Getty Images 1999, Jeff Gordon Gordon’s second Daytona 500 victory came from the pole in the No. 24 Hendrick Motorsports Chevrolet. He qualified at 195.067 mph. Sporting News Sporting News via Getty Images 2000, Dale Jarrett Jarrett won another Daytona 500 in his Robert Yates Racing Ford, this time from the pole, after qualifying at 191.091 mph. Getty Images Jamie Squire 2001, Bill Elliott Elliott’s pole was significant because it came in Dodge’s first race back in NASCAR. Elliott won the pole at 183.565 mph in one of Ray Evernham’s Dodge Intrepids. He wound up fifth in the race. This content is subject to copyright. Getty Images 2002, Jimmie Johnson In his rookie season, Johnson captured the Daytona 500 pole with a lap of 185.831 mph in his Hendrick Motorsports Chevrolet. He finished 15 th . This content is subject to copyright. Getty Images 2003, Jeff Green Green won just two poles in his Cup career. This one, at 186.606 mph in a Richard Childress Racing Chevrolet, was one of them. Unfortunately, a crash left him 39 th in the Daytona 500. Getty Images Getty Images 2004, Greg Biffle Sold effort for the Biff saw him claim the Daytona 500 pole at 188.387 mph in his Roush Fenway Racing Ford and finish 12 th in the race. Getty Images Getty Images 2005, Dale Jarrett Always tough at Daytona, Jarrett won the 500 pole at 188.312 mph in the No. 88 Robert Yates Racing Ford. He went on to finish 15 th in the race. Getty Images Getty Images 2006, Jeff Burton Burton had to be bummed at finishing 32 nd in the Daytona 500 after winning the pole at 189.151 mph in his Richard Childress Racing Chevrolet. This content is subject to copyright. MCT via Getty Images 2007, David Gilliland Robert Yates’ Fords always made lots of steam under the hood, as Gilliland showed by winning the pole at 186.320 mph. He finished eighth in the race. Getty Images Getty Images 2008, Jimmie Johnson Qualifying was great for Johnson, as he sat on pole with a speed of 187.075 mph. Unfortunately for him, we wound up 27 th in the Daytona 500. Getty Images Getty Images for NASCAR 2009, Martin Truex Jr. A nice effort for Truex, who took the pole at 189.001 mph in an Earnhardt Ganassi Racing Chevrolet and finished 11 th in the race. Getty Images Getty Images for NASCAR 2010, Mark Martin Driving a Hendrick Motorsports Chevrolet, Martin took the pole at 191.188 mph and finished 12 th in the race. Getty Images Getty Images for NASCAR 2011, Dale Earnhardt Jr. JR Nation’s hero won the pole at 186.089 mph, but it was Trevor Bayne who scored a huge upset as Earnhardt crashed and finished 24 th . Getty Images Getty Images for NASCAR 2012, Carl Edwards Edwards won the pole at 194.738 mph in his Roush Fenway Racing Ford and finished eighth. He never won a restrictor-plate race in his career. 2013, Danica Patrick A historic event, as Patrick became the first woman to win the Daytona 500 pole, clocking in at 196.434 mph. She finished eighth in the No. 10 Stewart-Haas Racing Chevrolet. MCT MCT via Getty Images 2014, Austin Dillon In the first return of the No. 3 to the Daytona 500 since the death of Dale Earnhardt, Dillon captured the pole with a speed of 196.019 mph in his Richard Childress Racing Chevrolet. In the race, he finished ninth. 2015, Jeff Gordon In his final Daytona 500, Gordon took the pole at 201.293 mph but finished 33 rd in his No. 24 Hendrick Motorsports Chevrolet. NASCAR NASCAR via Getty Images 2016, Chase Elliott Elliott became the youngest Daytona 500 pole-winner in history, qualifying at 196.314 mph and putting the No. 24 Hendrick Motorsports Chevrolet in the No. 1 slot for the second year in a row. But he crashed early in the race and finished 37 th . John Harrelson / LAT Photo USA
